body_text.section: Highly sensitive detection of the SARS-CoV-2 E and N genes 114

body_text.text: The sensitivity of RT-PCR is affected by various factors, such as the nucleic acid extraction 5 133 method, the one-step RT-PCR reagent, and the primer/probe sets. Optimization experiments 134 are required prior to using this methodology in clinical settings. 135 Current results indicate that: 1) the NIID-N set is slightly more sensitive than E_Sarbeco; 2) 136 NIID-N and E_Sarbeco are a good combination for detecting two regions of the SARS-CoV-2 137 genome with high sensitivity; and 3) the human ABL1 gene is useful as an IC for checking the 138 qualities of the specimen, nucleic acid extraction step, and RT-PCR amplification. Therefore, 139 we demonstrated that this highly sensitive multiplex rRT-PCR methodology can detect SARS-140 CoV-2.

The human ABL1 gene is recommended as an IC gene for the molecular diagnosis and 142 monitoring for minimal residual disease detection [7] . Many molecular diagnostic laboratories 143 use this primer/probe set. We did not use the ACTB and GAPDH genes, which are also 144 frequently used as ICs, because they are more abundantly expressed than the ABL1 gene [9].
In multiplex PCR, the amplification of highly abundant targets may prevent the amplification 146 of less abundant targets, possibly lowering the sensitivity of target detection.

FIGREF0.text: 10 nCOV_N (NIID-N) [3]. However, this method requires improvement as a molecular diagnostic 11 test used by clinical laboratories. The WHO recommended the detection of at least two different 12 targets on the COVID-19 virus genome. For example, Corman et al. recommended the E gene 13 assay as the first-line screening tool, followed by confirmatory testing with the RdRp gene 14 assay [2, 6]. However, our experiments and previous reports show that the N_Sarbeco set is 15 less sensitive than the NIID-N set [2,3]. In cases where NIID-N is weakly positive and 16 N_Sarbeco is negative, we have found it difficult to judge whether results are true positives or 17 false positives, indicating the need for another assay with sensitivity equal to the NIID-N set 18 to detect two regions of the COVID-19 genome with high sensitivity. In addition, an internal 19 control assay is required for evaluating the qualities of the specimen, nucleic acid extraction 20 step, and RT-PCR amplification [6]. 21 Here, we developed a multiplex rRT-PCR methodology for the simultaneous detection of two 22 regions of the SARS-CoV-2 genome (E and N genes), and of the human ABL1 gene. The 23 qualities of the clinical specimen and of the RT-PCR assay can be evaluated by using the 24 human ABL1 gene as an internal control (IC) [7].

FIGREF4.text: Sample preparation and viral RNA extraction 44 Thirty sputum samples from patients who underwent routine clinical SARS-CoV-2 tests 45 (simplex RT-PCR with NIID-N) were prepared using a DTT solution containing 20 mM DTT 46 in Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA). The sputum 47 samples were mixed well with the DTT solution at a volume ratio of 2:1. After incubation for 48 10 min at room temperature, the samples were centrifuged at 1500 × g for 5 min. Nucleic acids 49 were extracted from 200 μL of supernatant and viral RNA was extracted using a Maxwell RSC 50 Viral Total Nucleic Acid Purification Kit (Promega, Madison, WI, USA) using a Maxwell RSC 51 Instrument (Promega). Total nucleic acid was eluted in 50 μL of nuclease-free water.

FIGREF5.text: Cobas z 480 instrument (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany) was used for rRT-PCR.55    All reagents were brought to room temperature prior to preparing the master mix because56 preparing the mix on ice can result in occasional non-specific signal increases. Each 10-μL 57 reaction mixture contained 2.5 μL of 4× TaqPath 1-Step Multiplex Master Mix (No ROX; 58 Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA), 2.5 μL of 4× primer/probes mix, and 2.5 μL 59 of extracted total nucleic acid. The final concentrations of primers and probes were 0.2 μM 60 (target primers), 0.1 μM (target probes), 0.1 μM (IC primer), and 0.05 μM (IC probe). The 61 cycling program was as follows: uracil DNA glycosylase incubation at 37°C for 2 min; reverse 62 transcription at 55°C for 10 min; polymerase activation at 95°C for 2 min; and 45 cycles of 63 PCR at 95°C for 3 sec and 60°C for 30 sec (signal acquisition). The filter combinations were 64 465-510 (FAM), 540-580 (HEX), and 610-670 (Cy5). The melt factor, quant factor, and max 65 integration times were 1, 10, and 2 sec, respectively. No color compensation experiment was 66 performed because Cobas z 480 instruments contain calibrated filters. The C q One-step RT-PCR reagents and probe chemistries 72 Simplex rRT-PCR with NIID-N was performed using a synthetic RNA control with 2500 73 copies/reaction as the rRT-PCR template. Each experiment was performed in duplicate. First, 74 we compared the three one-step RT-PCR reagents TaqPath 1-Step Multiplex Master Mix, 75 QuantiTect Probe RT-PCR Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany), and LightCycler Multiplex RNA 76 Virus Master (Roche); the average C q values and standard deviations (SD) were 24.5 (0.11), 77 26.9 (0.064), and 26.8 (0.11), respectively. Second, we compared two probe chemistries: 78 FAM/TAMRA (a single-quenching probe) and FAM/ZEN/IBFQ (a double-quenching probe). 79 The average difference between the maximum and minimum fluorescence intensities and SD 80 were FAM/TAMRA 9.1 (0.21) and FAM/ZEN/IBFQ 10.1 (0.30). The signal-to-noise ratio was 81 11% higher using FAM/ZEN/IBFQ and thus TaqPath 1-Step Multiplex Master Mix and the 82 double-quenching probes were selected because of their low C q value and improved signal-to-83 noise ratio, respectively.
